item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Rhodium(III)‐Catalyzed Divergent C‐H Functionalization of N‐Aryl Amidines with Iodonium Ylides: Access to Carbazolones and Zwitterionic Salts
item.dc:description: We described an Rhodium(III)‐catalyzed divergent C‐H bond functionalization of N‐aryl amidines with iodonium ylides. Carbazolones and zwitterionic salts were diversely constructed through intermolecular annulation and intramolecular proton transfer under the different reaction conditions. This protocol is operationally simple and tolerates a variety of functional groups. The efficient post‐modification of pharmaceutical molecules demonstrates its practicability.
item.content:encoded: We described an Rhodium(III)-catalyzed divergent C-H bond functionalization of <i>N</i>-aryl amidines with iodonium ylides. Carbazolones and zwitterionic salts were diversely constructed through intermolecular annulation and intramolecular proton transfer under the different reaction conditions. This protocol is operationally simple and tolerates a variety of functional groups. The efficient post-modification of pharmaceutical molecules demonstrates its practicability.
item.dc:creator: Jie Ren, Liu Yang, Chao Pi, Xiuling Cui, Yangjie Wu
item.dc:title: Rhodium(III)‐Catalyzed Divergent C‐H Functionalization of N‐Aryl Amidines with Iodonium Ylides: Access to Carbazolones and Zwitterionic Salts

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of o‐Bis(3‐indolyl)arenes under Brønsted Acid Catalysis: Carbonyl Compounds as Sources of Aryl Groups
item.dc:description: Abstract A method of synthesizing o‐bis(3‐indolyl)arenes was developed by reacting indoles with 7‐oxabicyclo[2.2.1]hept‐5‐en‐2‐one and derivatives thereof having no aromatic ring. All 23 unknown o‐bis(3‐indolyl)arenes could be obtained using this method. Palladium catalysis is useful for enlarging the π‐conjugated area of o‐bis(3‐indolyl)arenes, delivering aryl‐, alkynyl‐, and alkenyl‐unit‐installed o‐bis(3‐indolyl)arenes, and benzo[c]indolo[2,3‐a]carbazoles, the derivatization to which is effective for raising fluorescence quantum yield. A possible reaction mechanism is proposed based on several mechanistic studies.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A method of synthesizing o-bis(3-indolyl)arenes was developed by reacting indoles with 7-oxabicyclo[2.2.1]hept-5-en-2-one and derivatives thereof having no aromatic ring. All 23 unknown o-bis(3-indolyl)arenes could be obtained using this method. Palladium catalysis is useful for enlarging the π-conjugated area of o-bis(3-indolyl)arenes, delivering aryl-, alkynyl-, and alkenyl-unit-installed o-bis(3-indolyl)arenes, and benzo[c]indolo[2,3-a]carbazoles, the derivatization to which is effective for raising fluorescence quantum yield. A possible reaction mechanism is proposed based on several mechanistic studies.
item.dc:creator: Rei Tokunaga, Takumi Okusa, Teruhisa Tsuchimoto
item.dc:title: Synthesis of o‐Bis(3‐indolyl)arenes under Brønsted Acid Catalysis: Carbonyl Compounds as Sources of Aryl Groups

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: A Scalable Synthesis of Chiral Himbert Diene Ligands for Asymmetric Catalysis
item.dc:description: Abstract Chiral dienes are important ligands in asymmetric catalysis but they are less accessible than other commonly used ligands such as chiral bisphosphines. Here, we show that intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition of a simply attained chiral allenecarboxanilide readily affords pseudoenantiomeric bicyclo[2.2.2]octa‐2,5‐dienes containing an alkenyl bromide, which can be readily functionalized to give diverse chiral diene ligands. The synthesis is straightforward and easily conducted on multigram scales. These ligands exhibit high performance in nine types of enantioselective Rh(I)‐catalyzed 1,4‐addition or 1,2‐addition reactions.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

Chiral dienes are important ligands in asymmetric catalysis but they are less accessible than other commonly used ligands such as chiral bisphosphines. Here, we show that intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition of a simply attained chiral allenecarboxanilide readily affords pseudoenantiomeric bicyclo[2.2.2]octa-2,5-dienes containing an alkenyl bromide, which can be readily functionalized to give diverse chiral diene ligands. The synthesis is straightforward and easily conducted on multigram scales. These ligands exhibit high performance in nine types of enantioselective Rh(I)-catalyzed 1,4-addition or 1,2-addition reactions.
item.dc:creator: Raja K. Rit, Hongyi Li, Stephen P. Argent, Katherine M. Wheelhouse, Simon Woodward, Hon Wai Lam
item.dc:title: A Scalable Synthesis of Chiral Himbert Diene Ligands for Asymmetric Catalysis

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Reactions Involving Multiple Isocyanide Insertions
item.dc:description: Abstract. Isocyanides (isonitriles or carbylamine) have been intensively used in organic synthesis to prepare a diverse variety of N‐heterocycles upon the carbene‐like reactivity of their divalent carbon atom. Isocyanides participate in a variety of reactions involving one, two or more isocyanides. Compared to the popularity of single isocyanide reactions, few examples of reactions involving two or more isocyanides have been reported. In this review, we categorized and classified the literatures of reactions involving two or more isocyanides especially double isocyanide insertions under metal‐catalyzed or metal‐free conditions from 2014 to 2022. Keywords: Isocyanides; Double insertion; Carbylamine; MCRs; Pd‐catalyzed reactions
item.content:encoded: Abstract. Isocyanides (isonitriles or carbylamine) have been intensively used in organic synthesis to prepare a diverse variety of N-heterocycles upon the carbene-like reactivity of their divalent carbon atom. Isocyanides participate in a variety of reactions involving one, two or more isocyanides. Compared to the popularity of single isocyanide reactions, few examples of reactions involving two or more isocyanides have been reported. In this review, we categorized and classified the literatures of reactions involving two or more isocyanides especially double isocyanide insertions under metal-catalyzed or metal-free conditions from 2014 to 2022. Keywords: Isocyanides; Double insertion; Carbylamine; MCRs; Pd-catalyzed reactions

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxidative Annulation of Aldehydes, 5‐Aminopyrazoles, and Nitriles: Synthesis and Applications of Pyrazolo[3,4‐d]Pyrimidines
item.dc:description: Abstract The oxidative [3+2+1] annulation reaction of aldehydes, 5‐aminopyrazoles, and nitriles is achieved under the oxidation of I2/O2, affording various valuable pyrazolo[3,4‐d]pyrimidines in 27%–91% yields. The salient feature of this reaction is transition‐metal free, operationally simple, broad substrate scope, good functional group tolerance, and gram‐scalable. Remarkably, the corresponding products exhibited intriguing photophysical properties such as Aggregation‐Induced Emission (AIE) and intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) and showed good potential to specifically light up lipid droplets (LDs) in living cells with bright fluorescence, low cytotoxicity, and good photostability.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

The oxidative [3+2+1] annulation reaction of aldehydes, 5-aminopyrazoles, and nitriles is achieved under the oxidation of I2/O2, affording various valuable pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidines in 27%–91% yields. The salient feature of this reaction is transition-metal free, operationally simple, broad substrate scope, good functional group tolerance, and gram-scalable. Remarkably, the corresponding products exhibited intriguing photophysical properties such as Aggregation-Induced Emission (AIE) and intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) and showed good potential to specifically light up lipid droplets (LDs) in living cells with bright fluorescence, low cytotoxicity, and good photostability.
item.dc:creator: Guangkai Yao, Chuanle Zhu, Tianyi Qin, Mengfan Wang, Zhixiu Sun, Ri‐Yuan Tang, Chen Zhao, Huanfeng Jiang, Hanhong Xu
item.dc:title: Oxidative Annulation of Aldehydes, 5‐Aminopyrazoles, and Nitriles: Synthesis and Applications of Pyrazolo[3,4‐d]Pyrimidines

item.title: β‐Functionalized and α,β‐Difunctionalized Ketones from 1‐Arylallylic Alcohols via Dipotassio α,β‐Dianion Intermediates.
item.dc:description: The front cover picture illustrates the synthesis of β‐functionalized and α,β‐difunctionalized ketones from 1‐arylallylic alcohols via dipotassio α,β‐dianion intermediates using (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium as the base. To reach the castle, a metaphor for the target product, a cannonball must hit the castle. Only cannonballs representing potassium bases reach the castle, whereas those of lithium and sodium bases fall into the woods. This implies that only potassium bases are effective in the synthesis. Details can be found in the Communication by Masahiro Sai and co‐workers (R. Hayashi, K. Ando, T. Udagawa, M. Sai, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2023, 365, XXXX–XXXX; DOI: 10.1002/adsc.202201047)
item.content:encoded: The front cover picture illustrates the synthesis of β-functionalized and α,β-difunctionalized ketones from 1-arylallylic alcohols via dipotassio α,β-dianion intermediates using (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium as the base. To reach the castle, a metaphor for the target product, a cannonball must hit the castle. Only cannonballs representing potassium bases reach the castle, whereas those of lithium and sodium bases fall into the woods. This implies that only potassium bases are effective in the synthesis. Details can be found in the Communication by Masahiro Sai and co-workers (R. Hayashi, K. Ando, T. Udagawa, M. Sai, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2023, 365, XXXX–XXXX; DOI: 10.1002/adsc.202201047)

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Developments in Enantioselective Domino Reactions. Part B: First Row Metal Catalysts
item.dc:description: Abstract This review updates the field of enantioselective domino reactions promoted by chiral catalysts derived from first row metals, such as zinc, iron, copper, scandium, nickel, cobalt, titanium, chromium and magnesium as special case, published since the beginning of 2019. It illustrates how much a diversity of these catalysts allow an impressive range of novel highly enantioselective domino reactions of many types to be achieved, providing a one‐pot access to very complex and functionalized chiral molecules from simple starting materials.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

This review updates the field of enantioselective domino reactions promoted by chiral catalysts derived from first row metals, such as zinc, iron, copper, scandium, nickel, cobalt, titanium, chromium and magnesium as special case, published since the beginning of 2019. It illustrates how much a diversity of these catalysts allow an impressive range of novel highly enantioselective domino reactions of many types to be achieved, providing a one-pot access to very complex and functionalized chiral molecules from simple starting materials.
item.dc:creator: Hélène Pellissier
item.dc:title: Recent Developments in Enantioselective Domino Reactions. Part B: First Row Metal Catalysts

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Developments in Enantioselective Domino Reactions. Part A: Noble Metal Catalysts
item.dc:description: Abstract This review updates the field of enantioselective domino reactions promoted by chiral catalysts derived from noble metals, including palladium, silver, rhodium, ruthenium, iridium and gold, published since the beginning of 2019. It illustrates how much a diversity of these catalysts allow unprecedented asymmetric domino reactions of many types to be achieved with excellent enantioselectivity, giving a direct access to a wide variety of complex chiral molecules.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

This review updates the field of enantioselective domino reactions promoted by chiral catalysts derived from noble metals, including palladium, silver, rhodium, ruthenium, iridium and gold, published since the beginning of 2019. It illustrates how much a diversity of these catalysts allow unprecedented asymmetric domino reactions of many types to be achieved with excellent enantioselectivity, giving a direct access to a wide variety of complex chiral molecules.
item.dc:creator: Hélène Pellissier
item.dc:title: Recent Developments in Enantioselective Domino Reactions. Part A: Noble Metal Catalysts

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Selective Catalytic Cross‐Cyclotrimerization En Route to1,4‐Diborylated Benzenes and Their Synthetic Transformations
item.dc:description: Abstract A synthesis of 1,4‐diborylated benzenes was achieved by the Ru‐catalyzed regioselective co‐cyclotrimerization of alkynes with a commercially available ethynyl boronate. The reaction is applicable to a wide array of alkynes with metal‐coordinating groups, providing synthetically useful diborylated benzenes in 23–68% isolated yields. DFT calculations shed light on the reaction course and the origin of its remarkable regioselectivity. Selected diborylated benzenes were converted into various products, such as quinones and hydroquinones, including three natural bioactive small molecules.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A synthesis of 1,4-diborylated benzenes was achieved by the Ru-catalyzed regioselective co-cyclotrimerization of alkynes with a commercially available ethynyl boronate. The reaction is applicable to a wide array of alkynes with metal-coordinating groups, providing synthetically useful diborylated benzenes in 23–68% isolated yields. DFT calculations shed light on the reaction course and the origin of its remarkable regioselectivity. Selected diborylated benzenes were converted into various products, such as quinones and hydroquinones, including three natural bioactive small molecules.
item.dc:creator: Alexander A. Fadeev, Gabriele Manca, Martin Kotora
item.dc:title: Selective Catalytic Cross‐Cyclotrimerization En Route to1,4‐Diborylated Benzenes and Their Synthetic Transformations

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Direct C−H Amination of Quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones
item.dc:description: Abstract A visible‐light‐induced direct C(sp2)−H amination of quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones toward the synthesis of substituted 3‐aminoquinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones with TMSN3 has been firstly developed. This transformation achieved C(sp2)−H/N−H coupling in the absence of external ligand and oxidant. Notably, this methodology features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope and operational simplicity.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A visible-light-induced direct C(sp 2)−H amination of quinoxalin-2(1H)-ones toward the synthesis of substituted 3-aminoquinoxalin-2(1H)-ones with TMSN3 has been firstly developed. This transformation achieved C(sp 2)−H/N−H coupling in the absence of external ligand and oxidant. Notably, this methodology features mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope and operational simplicity.
item.dc:creator: Yanpeng Liu, Congcong Pei, Xiaoyu Chen, Jianye Zhang, Jingya Li, Dapeng Zou, Yangjie Wu, Yusheng Wu
item.dc:title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Direct C−H Amination of Quinoxalin‐2(1H)‐ones

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Pot Construction of Fluorinated Chiral Alcohols via Sequential Substitution/Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of α‐Bromoarylketones and Fluoroalcohols
item.dc:description: Abstract A one‐pot synthesis of fluorinated chiral alcohols from α‐bromoarylketones and fluoroalcohols is described. The fluorinated ketone intermediates were formed from α‐bromoarylketones with fluoroalcohols as nucleophiles and solvents, which were reduced subsequentially by adding a chiral Ru catalyst and a mixture of formic acid and triethyl amines (FA: TEA=1.1:1) as hydrogen donor to give 27 examples of fluorinated chiral alcohols in 60–93% yields and 85–98% ee values. Notably, K3PO4 acts as a base in nucleophilic substitution and an additive in reductive step to enhance the reactivity and enantioselectivity, which is crucial for constructing compatible conditions for one‐pot process. This one‐pot process is also applicable to gram‐scale synthesis.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

A one-pot synthesis of fluorinated chiral alcohols from α-bromoarylketones and fluoroalcohols is described. The fluorinated ketone intermediates were formed from α-bromoarylketones with fluoroalcohols as nucleophiles and solvents, which were reduced subsequentially by adding a chiral Ru catalyst and a mixture of formic acid and triethyl amines (FA: TEA=1.1:1) as hydrogen donor to give 27 examples of fluorinated chiral alcohols in 60–93% yields and 85–98% ee values. Notably, K3PO4 acts as a base in nucleophilic substitution and an additive in reductive step to enhance the reactivity and enantioselectivity, which is crucial for constructing compatible conditions for one-pot process. This one-pot process is also applicable to gram-scale synthesis.
item.dc:creator: Rongrong Zhao, Qiao Wei, Yuxin Huang, Qin Qu, Qixing Liu, Haifeng Zhou
item.dc:title: One‐Pot Construction of Fluorinated Chiral Alcohols via Sequential Substitution/Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of α‐Bromoarylketones and Fluoroalcohols

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: β‐Functionalized and α,β‐Difunctionalized Ketones from 1‐Arylallylic Alcohols via Dipotassio α,β‐Dianion Intermediates
item.dc:description: Abstract This study reports the synthesis of diverse β‐functionalized ketones from readily available 1‐arylallylic alcohols in the presence of (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium (TMSCH2K). The reaction proceeded via the formation of the highly nucleophilic dipotassio α,β‐dianion as the key intermediate, which served as a metal homoenolate equivalent. This protocol also allowed the one‐pot synthesis of α,β‐difunctionalized ketones using two different electrophiles, thus demonstrating its synthetic advantages over other protocols involving metal homoenolates.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

This study reports the synthesis of diverse β-functionalized ketones from readily available 1-arylallylic alcohols in the presence of (trimethylsilyl)methylpotassium (TMSCH2K). The reaction proceeded via the formation of the highly nucleophilic dipotassio α,β-dianion as the key intermediate, which served as a metal homoenolate equivalent. This protocol also allowed the one-pot synthesis of α,β-difunctionalized ketones using two different electrophiles, thus demonstrating its synthetic advantages over other protocols involving metal homoenolates.
item.dc:creator: Rikuo Hayashi, Kaori Ando, Taro Udagawa, Masahiro Sai
item.dc:title: β‐Functionalized and α,β‐Difunctionalized Ketones from 1‐Arylallylic Alcohols via Dipotassio α,β‐Dianion Intermediates

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Direct Suzuki‐Miyaura Coupling of Naphthalene‐1,8‐diaminato (dan)‐Substituted Cyclopropylboron Compounds
item.dc:description: Abstract We herein describe the direct Suzuki‐Miyaura coupling of dan‐substituted, saturated organoboron compounds. Despite its Lewis acidity‐diminished character of the boron center, cyclopropyl‐B(dan) can be activated by t‐BuOK to undergo transmetalation with a palladium complex. The increased s‐character of the C−B(dan) bond as compared with other alkyl‐B(dan) should be the key to the reaction.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

We herein describe the direct Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of dan-substituted, saturated organoboron compounds. Despite its Lewis acidity-diminished character of the boron center, cyclopropyl-B(dan) can be activated by t-BuOK to undergo transmetalation with a palladium complex. The increased s-character of the C−B(dan) bond as compared with other alkyl-B(dan) should be the key to the reaction.
item.dc:creator: Mikinao Koishi, Kazuki Tomota, Masaaki Nakamoto, Hiroto Yoshida
item.dc:title: Direct Suzuki‐Miyaura Coupling of Naphthalene‐1,8‐diaminato (dan)‐Substituted Cyclopropylboron Compounds

item.source: Wiley: Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis: Table of Contents
item.title: Unexpected Stereoselective Access to 2‐Aminooxazolines from Propargyl Ureas by Silver Salts under Mild Conditions
item.dc:description: Abstract Propargyl ureas can lead to a range of possible heterocyclic compounds, mainly depending on the employed catalyst. Silver salts are known to promote the N‐5‐exo‐dig cyclization mode to imidazolidinone derivatives. Conversely, a versatile and stereoselective O‐5‐exo‐dig cyclization of propargyl ureas to 2‐aminooxazolines by Ag(I) catalysis is here disclosed. Good to excellent yields and complete stereoselectivity of the external double bond have been achieved under milder reaction conditions (50–60 °C). A one‐pot protocol starting from the corresponding propargylic amines and isocyanates has been developed as well. N,N’‐Dipropargyl ureas underwent a uncommon O‐5‐exo‐dig/N‐5‐endo‐dig double cyclization sequence. Finally, insights into the tautomeric equilibrium of 2‐aminooxazoles and on their relative reactivity are provided.
item.content:encoded:
Abstract

Propargyl ureas can lead to a range of possible heterocyclic compounds, mainly depending on the employed catalyst. Silver salts are known to promote the N-5-exo-dig cyclization mode to imidazolidinone derivatives. Conversely, a versatile and stereoselective O-5-exo-dig cyclization of propargyl ureas to 2-aminooxazolines by Ag(I) catalysis is here disclosed. Good to excellent yields and complete stereoselectivity of the external double bond have been achieved under milder reaction conditions (50–60 °C). A one-pot protocol starting from the corresponding propargylic amines and isocyanates has been developed as well. N,N’-Dipropargyl ureas underwent a uncommon O-5-exo-dig/N-5-endo-dig double cyclization sequence. Finally, insights into the tautomeric equilibrium of 2-aminooxazoles and on their relative reactivity are provided.
item.dc:creator: Aleksandr Voronov, Alessandra Casnati, Paolo P. Mazzeo, Paolo Pelagatti, Alessia Bacchi, Raffaella Mancuso, Bartolo Gabriele, Elena Motti, Giovanni Maestri, Péter Pál Fehér, András Stirling, Nicola Della Ca'
item.dc:title: Unexpected Stereoselective Access to 2‐Aminooxazolines from Propargyl Ureas by Silver Salts under Mild Conditions
